newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot natgas continues to rally with futures.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot natgas continues to rally with futures.

text.p: U.S. spot natural gas prices closed the gap with futures Tuesday, resulting in another significant gain in most cash markets, sources said.
On the Louisiana Gulf Coast, swing prices at the Henry Hub were quoted up an average of seven cents to about $2.30-2.35 as utility buyers re-emerged for additional supplies.
By mid-morning, futures and cash were for the most part in convergence as September futures traded around $2.34-2.35.
In the Midwest, swing prices soared into the mid-$2.20s, gaining about 10 cents from Monday. Chicago city-gate gas prices were up an equal amount to about $2.40.
In the Permian Basin market, prices rose another 10 cents to $2.25-2.26 in tandem with surging electricity prices due to the heat.
Prices in Palo Verde for next-day delivery peak loads were quoted at $55.00-65.00 per megawatt hour, up about $20 from Monday.
Triggering the onslaught of buying interest in the West were temperature highs topping 100 degrees F in many parts of the region.
San Juan basin gas was also several cents higher at $2.20-2.23, while southern California border prices soared to about $2.40-2.41.

The strength in the Gulf and Midcontinent markets filtered into the eastern market areas, traders said. As a result, the New York city gate market shrugged off cooler-than-normal weather by climbing to the low-$2.50s, from the low-to-mid $2.40s on Monday.
